\begin{abstract}
Consider a group $\Gamma$ acting on a formal (Fedosov) deformation quantization ${\mathbb{A}_\hbar}(M)$ of a symplectic manifold $(M,\omega)$. This canonically induces an action of $\Gamma$ by symplectomorphisms
on $M$. We examine the reverse problem of extending group actions by symplectomorphisms to the deformation quantization. To do this we first define a notion of extension that does not 
impose restrictions on the Fedosov connection realizing ${\mathbb{A}_\hbar}(M)$ in its gauge equivalence class by considering composition of pull-back with certain inner automorphisms of sections of the 
Weyl bundle. We reformulate the well known sufficient conditions for existence of such extensions and 
show by way of example that they are not necessary. We then turn to the corresponding classification problem of extensions of a given action by symplectomorphisms. To this end we associate 
a group ${\overline{\mathcal{G}_\nabla}}$ to each Fedosov connection $\nabla$ and show that the (non-Abelian) group cohomology ${\mbox{H}}^1(\Gamma,{\overline{\mathcal{G}_\nabla}})$ classifies extensions up to a natural notion 
of equivalence. Finally we develop several tools that allow for computation of ${\mbox{H}}^1(\Gamma,{\overline{\mathcal{G}_\nabla}})$ and apply these to compute ${\mbox{H}}^1(\Gamma,{\overline{\mathcal{G}_\nabla}})$ in a range of examples. 



\end{abstract}

\section{Introduction}

\subsection{Background} 

The concept of deformation quantization and in particular formal deformation quantization was famously introduced in the influential paper \cite{BFFLS} and has been exstensively studied 
since then. It phrases the problem of quantization of physical systems in terms of the mathematical notion of formal deformations of algebras developed by Gerstenhaber in the series of 
papers 
\cite{G1, G2, G3}. One of the main achievements in the field is of course Kontsevich's classification of the formal deformation quantizations of Poisson manifolds \cite{Kont}. It is however 
relevant to note that Fedosov had essentially performed such a classification in the case of symplectic manifolds \cite{Fb, Fp} (which are arguably the ones most encountered in 
physics) earlier.

\vspace{0.3cm}

One of the advantages noted in Fedosov's original paper is that there is a simple way to lift any symplectomorphism of the manifold to an automorphism of the deformation 
quantization. It pays to keep in mind however that these lifts do not obviously respect compositions and are in general not unique. Since 
group actions of the symplectic manifold can be interpreted as symmetries of the classical mechanical system, the question of whether one can lift a group action naturally arises and 
Fedosov comments on this in his original paper \cite{Fp}. 

\vspace{0.3cm}

Another reason why this question arises is in the context of the algebraic index theorem \cite{N-T95, Fp}. The main observation underlying this theorem is that the pseudo-differential 
operators on a smooth manifold form a deformation quantization of the cotangent bundle of that manifold (with the canonical symplectic structure). 
Given this observation the algebraic index theorem 
is the algebraic counterpart of the Atiyah-Singer index theorem \cite{A-S}. Note that the algebraic index theorem can be shown for any deformation quantization of any symplectic manifold however
(not just cotangent bundles and pseudo-differential operators). It was also shown by Nest-Tsygan 
in \cite{N-T96} that one can rederive the (analytic) index theorem from the algebraic one. If we now consider a manifold carrying a group action (or a foliation) it leads to the equivariant 
(resp transversal) index theorem \cite{C-M, P-R}. Therefore it makes sense to expect algebraic counterparts to these theorems as well. This makes even more sense since these counterparts 
were found for orbifolds \cite{Post}. In order to derive such an equivariant algebraic index theorem in general, we should first understand the nature of induced group actions on deformation 
quantization and this paper addresses that issue. 

\vspace{0.3cm}

Some work towards both the classification and existence results of such group actions on formal deformation quantizations of symplectic manifolds was in fact already carried out. 
First of all Fedosov comments on the problem in both his original paper and his book \cite{Fp, Fb}. Furthermore, when one restricts to so called invariant star products (a definition will 
follow),  a classification up to equivariant equivalence was found by Bertelsoni-Bieliavsky-Gutt 
\cite{Ginvariant} and recently this classification was extended to include a notion of quantum moment maps by Reichert-Waldmann \cite{RW}. In this paper we will extend these considerations to provide some 
(limited) existence results and (extensive) classification results for group actions on symplectic 
manifolds, where we consider any  extensions to the deformation quantization. The reason to consider more than the natural extensions is explained in \ref{why}.








\subsection{Set-up, Notation and Convention} 
Let us now be more precise about the concepts mentioned above and at the same time introduce the notations and conventions used in this paper.

First of all we will consider only symplectic manifolds $(M,\omega)$ of dimension $2n$. We will denote by $\{\cdot,\cdot\}$ the corresponding 
Poisson bracket on the algebra $C^\infty(M)$ of complex valued smooth functions on $M$. We will indeed always consider complex valued functions and thus also complex valued cohomology. 
Furthermore let us fix for the rest of this paper the formal variable $\hbar$. Often vector spaces and linear maps will be over the ring ${\mathbb{C}}{[\![\hbar]\!]}$ of formal power series with coefficients 
in ${\mathbb{C}}$.

The top row and right column are given entirely by Abelian groups ($\mathcal{Z}^\times\simeq C^\infty(M){[\![\hbar]\!]}^\times$). The diagram allows us to show that under suffient cohomological 
restrictions on $\Gamma$ and $M$ we have that ${\mbox{H}}^1(\Gamma,{\overline{\mathcal{G}_\nabla}})=\{1\}$ and so up to conjugation by a fixed automorphism the extension of the group action is unique \ref{casefsphere}. 
We also give examples where these conditions are not satisfied and ${\mbox{H}}^1(\Gamma,{\overline{\mathcal{G}_\nabla}})$ is not trivial. In these cases we give some description of a parametrization of 
the set ${\mbox{H}}^1(\Gamma,{\overline{\mathcal{G}_\nabla}})$ (see \ref{T2irr} and \ref{Zaction}).

\section{Fedosov Construction}

In this section we will give a brief reminder of the Fedosov construction for symplectic manifolds, see \cite{Fp, Fb, N-T99, W} for more in depth expositions of the construction. 
The Fedosov construction allows one to construct any 
deformation quantization of a symplectic manifold (up to gauge equivalence) as a subalgebra of a certain algebra of sections. Let us first show how one can construct the underlying bundle of 
algebras, the so called \emph{Weyl bundle}. 

\begin{definition} 
  
  Denote by ${\mathbb{W}}\colon SymV_{\mathbb{C}}\longrightarrow GrA_{{\mathbb{C}}{[\![\hbar]\!]}}$ the Weyl functor from the category of complex symplectic vector spaces to the category of graded associative algebras over ${\mathbb{C}}{[\![\hbar]\!]}$ given by

 \end{definition}
 
 \begin{notation}
  Given ${\mathbb{R}}^{2m}$ ($m\in{\mathbb{N}}$) with the standard symplectic structure $\omega_{st}$ we construct the standard complex symplectic vector 
space by considering ${\mathbb{C}}^{2m}={\mathbb{R}}^{2m}\otimes_{\mathbb{R}}{\mathbb{C}}$ with the symplectic structure 
$\eta_{st}=\omega_{st}\otimes_{\mathbb{R}} 1$. Then we will denote ${\mathbb{W}}_{\hbar,m}:={\mathbb{W}}\left({\mathbb{C}}^{2m},\eta_{st}\right)$ (we will usually simply denote it  ${\mathbb{W}}_\hbar$ if the dimension is implied). 
\end{notation}

\begin{remark}
 We have chosen to follow the construction as laid out in \cite{N-T99}, in order to follow it as in \cite{Fp, Fb, W} one would consider, instead of ${\mathbb{W}}$, the 
 functor that associates to a symplectic vector space the algebra of formal power series in the symmetric algebra and equip it with a deformed product. Thus it 
 pays to keep in mind that both these algebras are quotients of the 
 tensor algebra and the well known section of the symmetric algebra
prevtext: where the ideal $I_\alpha\subset TV{[\![\hbar]\!]}$ is generated by the elements

nexttext:
where $\vee$ denotes the symmetric product, composes with the quotient map to a linear isomorphism from the symmetric algebra to the Weyl algebra. The deformed product on the former is induced 
 from this linear isomorphism. The symmetric algebra has the advantage of being graded by the total grading like the Weyl algebra, 
 but, for the undeformed product, also by the tensor grading (so $v_1\vee\ldots\vee v_k$ with all $v_j\in V$ has tensor degree $k$) and the $\hbar$ grading seperately.  
 On the other hand the Weyl algebra allows certain operators that will be important in
 the following to be expressed straightforwardly and globally. Also the product on the Weyl algebra allows for a global expression on the nose, while the deformed product on the symmetric 
 algebra is given by a local formula that is easily shown to define a global product. Another advantage of the Weyl algebra is that it can be considered as the infinity jets of the Moyal-Weyl deformation of 
 $\left(V,\alpha\right)$ at the origin and in the same way 
 the fibers of the corresponding Weyl bundle (defined below) can be viewed as infinity jets of a deformation quantization of the underlying symplectic manifold \cite{N-T99}. 
 \end{remark}

\begin{remark}
\leavevmode
 \begin{description}
 \setlength{\itemsep}{.01mm}
  \item[-] The definition makes sense since $\nabla_0\left(i\hbar{\bar{\omega}}\left(v,w\right)\right)=i\hbar{\bar{\omega}}\left(\nabla_0v,w\right)+i\hbar{\bar{\omega}}\left(v,\nabla_0w\right)$ for any affine 
  symplectic connection and thus we may extend it to
${\mathcal{W}}$.
\item[-] Given any connection $\nabla$ on ${\mathcal{W}}$ we find that $\nabla-\nabla_0\in{\operatorname{\mbox{Der}}}\left({\mathcal{W}}\right)$, where by ${\operatorname{\mbox{Der}}}\left({\mathcal{W}}\right)$ we mean sections of the bundle with fibers ${\mathfrak{g}}$.
\item[-] The condition of being Fedosov simply states that $\nabla$ is flat and has a 
specific degree $-1$ part. The degree $0$ part being given by a symplectic connection can be assumed.
\item[-] Although the one-form $A_{-1}$ was defined using the symplectic 
structure one checks that $[A_{-1},-]$ is diffeomorphism invariant since the $\omega$ in $A_{-1}$ cancels against the ${\bar{\omega}}$ coming from $[-,-]$.
 \end{description}

\end{remark}


\begin{notation} We will denote 
$A=A_{-1}+A_1+A_2+\ldots$ and $A_{\mathbb{N}}=A-A_{-1}$ with corresponding Fedosov connection $\nabla_A=\nabla_0+[A,-]$. We denote the curvature of the connection $\nabla_A$ by
$\Omega_A:=\frac{R_0}{i\hbar}+\nabla_0\left(A_{\mathbb{N}}\right)+[A_{-1},A_{\mathbb{N}}]+\frac{1}{2}[A_{\mathbb{N}},A_{\mathbb{N}}]$.\end{notation} Note that for a Fedosov connection, since $\nabla_A^2=[\Omega_A,-]$, $\Omega_A$ is central and, since $\nabla_A\Omega_A=0$, closed \cite{Fb}. 


\begin{theorem} 
 For all closed forms $\theta\in\Omega^2\left(M,{\mathbb{C}}\right){[\![\hbar]\!]}$ we can find a Fedosov connection $\nabla_\theta$ such that the curvature $\Omega_\theta=\frac{\omega}{2i\hbar}+\theta$. 
\end{theorem}

See \cite{N-T99}, \cite{Fb}, \cite {W} for a proof of this theorem. Thus we see that  there is a surjective mapping $\nabla_A\mapsto \Omega_A-\frac{\omega}{2i\hbar}$ from the set of Fedosov 
connections to $Z^2\left(M\right){[\![\hbar]\!]}$ were $Z^2\left(M\right)$ denotes
the space of closed two forms. The above theorem sets up to classify all deformation quantizations of $C^\infty\left(M\right)$ (up to gauge equivalence) by ${\mbox{H}}^2\left(M\right){[\![\hbar]\!]}$ by the following
theorem.
\begin{theorem}
 Suppose $\nabla$ is  a Fedosov connection and denote ${\mathbb{A}_\hbar}_\nabla:=\ker \nabla\cap\Omega^0\left(M,{\mathcal{W}}\right)$ then there exists a linear isomorphism 
 $Q\colon C^\infty\left(M\right){[\![\hbar]\!]}\rightarrow{\mathbb{A}_\hbar}_\nabla$ such that the 
 algebra structure pulled back under $Q$ is a deformation quantization. 
\end{theorem}
In \cite{Fp, Fb} and \cite{W} the map $\sigma=Q^{-1}$ is given by simply projecting down to the tensor degree $0$. In \cite{N-T99} this gradation is not available and the map is defined by 
cohomological 
reasoning as for the case of recovering smooth functions in Gelfand-Kazhdan's formal geometry, see for instance \cite{formal}. 
In practice we will simply consider the algebra ${\mathbb{A}_\hbar}_\nabla$ and thus we shall not go into the detail of the definition of $\sigma$. 
\begin{theorem} 
 For ${\mathbb{A}_\hbar}\left(M\right)$ a deformation quantization of $M$ there exists a Fedosov connection $\nabla$ such that ${\mathbb{A}_\hbar}_\nabla\simeq {\mathbb{A}_\hbar}\left(M\right)$ by the map $\sigma$ followed by a gauge 
 equivalence $T$. 
\end{theorem}
A proof of this theorem may be found in \cite{N-T99}. The main argument is that one can extend the deformed product to jets of functions and so doing construct an isomorphism of jets with 
sections of ${\mathcal{W}}$. Under this isomorphism 
the 
canonical connection on jets gets mapped to a Fedosov connection. To finish the classification of deformation quantizations of $M$ we have the following theorem. 
\begin{theorem}\label{classification}
 Suppose $\nabla_A$, $\nabla_{A'}$ are two Fedosov connections then ${\mathbb{A}_\hbar}_{\nabla_A}\simeq {\mathbb{A}_\hbar}_{\nabla_{A'}}$ if and only if 
 $[\Omega_A-\frac{\omega}{2i\hbar}]=[\Omega_{A'}-\frac{\omega}{2i\hbar}]\in {\mbox{H}}^2\left(M\right){[\![\hbar]\!]}$. 
\end{theorem}
Again the proof may be found in \cite{N-T99} and the proof  of the ``if'' statement is given by constructing degree by degree an inner automorphism of sections of the Weyl bundle such that
conjugation by this inner automorphism maps 
one connection to the other. The main 
tool that is used is acyclicity of the complex with differential $[A_{-1},-]$. The ``only if'' statement follows again from the observation that one can extend the deformation to jets and 
the isomorphism implies an 
isomorphism of the corresponding algebras of jets. The above theorems combine to imply that $H^2\left(M\right){[\![\hbar]\!]}$, or rather $\frac{\omega}{2i\hbar}+H^2\left(M\right){[\![\hbar]\!]}$, completely 
classifies formal deformation quantizations of the symplectic 
manifold $M$ up to gauge equivalence. In the following we will sometimes refer to the class in $H^2\left(M\right){[\![\hbar]\!]}$ as the \emph{characteristic} class since the 
translation by $\frac{\omega}{2i\hbar}$ will often not play a role.

 denoted by $z$ the zero-section of 
 $T^*S^2\rightarrow S^2$ and by $f_\sharp$ the symplectomorphism of $T^*S^2$ induced by $f$. However note that any non-zero two-form on $S^2$ will have support on some open $U$ which is disjoint 
 from $Eq(S^1)$ and subject to a multitude of ``local'' diffeomorphisms in $\Gamma$. So since $\omega+dz^*\theta$ is invariant under all such diffeomorphisms we find that it vanishes identically,
 but this implies that $[\omega]=0$. Thus we are led to a contradiction, which shows that $[\omega]$ is not in the image of the map \ref{equivmap}, in fact this map is $0$. 
  Thus this action does not satisfy the criteria of \ref{trivialextensions} and there does not exist any invariant Fedosov connection with non-trivial characteristic class for this action. 
  On the other hand, we note that, by considering the clutching construction of vector bundles on $S^2$, we can lift the action of $\Gamma$ to an action on the line bundle corresponding to the 
  inclusion $S^1\hookrightarrow {\mathbb{C}}^\times$ (which has Chern class $[\omega]$). This means we can extend the action of $\Gamma$ to differential operators on smooth sections of this line bundle. 
  Thus by the results in \cite{repline} we find that the action of $\Gamma$ does lift to the deformation quantization with characteristic class $\hbar[\pi^*\omega]$. 
  
  
\end{example} 

By \ref{worthexample} we see that although the conditions of \ref{trivialextensions} are sufficient to conclude existence of extended group actions (as defined in \ref{extendaction}) they 
are not necessary. 

\vspace{0.3cm}

It is notable that by the results in \cite{repline} the question of lifting an action to deformation quantization reduces, in the case of deformations of cotangent bundles with 
characteristic classes as in \ref{worthexample}, to lifting the action from the manifold to a line bundle with the corresponding Chern class. This last problem essentially comes down to 
showing that the Chern class extends to an equivariant class. Thus \ref{cocyclecond} seems to imply there is a deformation quantization analog of equivariant cohomology for which the 
extension of the characteristic class to an equivariant class is a necessary and sufficient condition for the action to extend to the corresponding deformation.

\end{theorem}

Which means the sequence $S_k\left(i,j\right)$ is Cauchy in ${\mathbb{A}_\hbar}$ (which is complete) and therefore has a limit $S_\infty\left(i,j\right)\in{\mathbb{A}_\hbar}$ for all 
 $\left(i,j\right)\in J^2$. Now note that since all the $S_k$ have values in $({{\mathbb{A}_\hbar}}^\times)_1$ so does $S_\infty$.
 Similarly we can show that the sequence $b_k$ has a limit $b\colon J\rightarrow ({{\mathbb{A}_\hbar}}^\times)_1$. Moreover by the same computation we see that $S_\infty=b\cdot S$. In particular 
 $S$ is 
 cohomologous to $S_\infty$ and since $\varprojlim \left({{\mathbb{A}_\hbar}}^\times\right)_n=1$ 
 we see that $[S]=[1]\in{\check{\mathrm{H}}}^1(\mathcal{U},({{\mathbb{A}_\hbar}}^\times)_1)$. Since we started with an arbitrary cocycle this shows that the last cohomology pointed 
 set is in fact trivial. This shows the claim about $P_2$ and an easier 
 version of the same argument shows that $P_1$ is injective (since this is a group homomorphism). But since 
 $C^\infty\left(M\right){[\![\hbar]\!]}^\times\simeq C^\infty\left(M\right)^\times\times\left(1+\hbar C^\infty\left(M\right){[\![\hbar]\!]}\right)$ in the obvious way we see that $P_1$ is 
 also surjective. 
 
 \vspace{0.3cm}
 
 The  map $P_3$ is simply induced by $\exp$ from \ref{expLog}. 
 
\end{proof}
 
 \begin{remark} To show \ref{P1P2P3} we have used a method to pass from cohomology of ${\mathbb{A}_\hbar}^\times$ to cohomology of $C^\infty(M)^\times$ by showing that 
  ${\check{\mathrm{H}}}^1\left(\mathcal{U},\left({\mathbb{A}_\hbar}^\times\right)_1\right)=\{1\}$, using that ${\check{\mathrm{H}}}^1\left(\mathcal{U},C^\infty(M)\right)$ vanishes. This method works equally well for group cohomology when 
  ${\mbox{H}}^1\left(\Gamma,C^\infty(M))\right)$ vanishes and we will use it in the next section simply referring to the proof of \ref{P1P2P3} instead of basically repeating the proof. Note that in general 
  the method provides an indication of how the cohomology of ${\mathbb{A}_\hbar}^\times$ and $C^\infty(M){[\![\hbar]\!]}^\times$ are both given by infinitely many copies of the cohomology of $C^\infty(M)$ and the 
  cohomology of $C^\infty(M)^\times$. 
 \end{remark}

 Now let $H\colon{\mbox{Im}\hspace{0.1cm}} {\mathbb{D}}\rightarrow {\check{\mathrm{H}}}^1\left(\mathcal{U},{\mathbb{C}}{[\![\hbar]\!]}^\times\right)$ be the map given as $H\left({\mathbb{D}} g\right)=[\eta]$ where 
 $\eta\left(i,j\right)=\frac{f\left(i\right)}{f\left(j\right)}$ with the $f(i)$ given by the decompositions $g|_{U_i}=f\left(i\right)\cdot k\left(i\right)$. Again we leave it to the reader

 $cr_\theta^*(g)=c'g$, where we denote by $r_\theta$ the rotation inducing the action of ${\mathbb{Z}}$. Then note that since the action has a fixed point at the north pole we can evaluate $g$ there 
 to find that $c=c'$. So we find that the map ${\mathbb{C}}{[\![\hbar]\!]}^\times\rightarrow {\mathbb{A}_\hbar}^\times/{\sim}$ is in fact injective. Now suppose $f\in{\mathbb{A}_\hbar}^\times$ such that there is $c\in{\mathbb{C}}{[\![\hbar]\!]}^\times$ and 
 $c\sim f$. Then if we write $c=\sum \hbar^kc_k$ and $f=\sum \hbar^kf_k$ we find that there exists some $g_0\in C^\infty(S^2)^\times$ such that 
 $c_0r_\theta^*(g_0)=f_0g_0$ (for the undeformed product). Now note that this implies that $f_0$ must take the value $c_0$ at both the north and south pole. So we find that the map 
 ${\mathbb{C}}{[\![\hbar]\!]}^\times\rightarrow {\mathbb{A}_\hbar}^\times/{\sim}$ is definitely not surjective, since there exist many non-vanishing functions on $S^2$ that do not have the same value at the north and 
 south pole. Then exactness of \ref{seqS2irr} shows that $H^1({\mathbb{Z}},{\overline{\mathcal{G}_\nabla}})\simeq {\overline{\mathcal{G}_\nabla}}/{\sim}\neq \{1\}$ and so there exist multiple extensions of this action to any deformation quantization. 
\end{example}

\begin{corollary} 
 Suppose $\Gamma={\mathbb{Z}}$ acts on $(M,\omega)$ with ${\mbox{H}}^1(M)=0$ and there is more than $1$ fixed point then ${\mbox{H}}^1(\Gamma,{\overline{\mathcal{G}_\nabla}})\neq\{1\}$. 
\end{corollary}
